persons.name: Pythagoras
persons.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

places.name: Crotone
places.description: a port city in Calabria, southern Italy. Founded c. 710 BC as the Achaean colony of Kroton it became a great Greek city, home of the renowned mathematician-philosopher Pythagoras.

places.name: Samos
places.description: A Greek island in the eastern Aegean Sea, separated from Turkey by the mile-wide Mycale Strait. It was the birthplace of mathematician Pythagoras and philosopher Epicurus.

persons.name: Plutarch
persons.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

persons.name: Leucippus
persons.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher. He is traditionally credited as the founder of atomism, which he developed with his student Democritus. Leucippus divided the world into two entities: atoms, indivisible particles that make up all things, and the void, the nothingness that exists between the atoms.

persons.name: Zeno
persons.description: of Elea, a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher

places.name: Abdera
places.description: a municipality in the Xanthi regional unit of Thrace, Greece. In classical antiquity, it was a major Greek polis on the Thracian coast.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Aristophanes
persons.description: a comic playwright or comedy-writer of ancient Athens and a poet of Old Attic Comedy.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Plato

Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Aristotle

He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Alexander III
persons.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

persons.name: ThomasAquinas
persons.description: Italian Dominican friar and priest, an influential philosopher and theologian, and a jurist in the tradition of scholasticism from the county of Aquino in the Kingdom of Sicily. Thomas was a prominent proponent of natural theology and the father of a school of thought known as Thomism.

He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Theophrastus
persons.description: A Greek philosopher and the successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school.

places.name: Liguria
places.description: Liguria is a region of north west Italy. Its capital is Genoa.

places.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

persons.name: Leucippus
persons.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher. He is traditionally credited as the founder of atomism, which he developed with his student Democritus. Leucippus divided the world into two entities: atoms, indivisible particles that make up all things, and the void, the nothingness that exists between the atoms.

persons.name: Democritus
persons.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

persons.name: Epicurus
persons.description: Ancient Greek philosopher, an atomist and materialist, following in the steps of Democritus and founder of Epicureanism.

persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

persons.description: a biographer of the Greek philosophers

persons.name: Lucretius
persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

persons.name: Phaedrus
persons.description: an ancient Athenian aristocrat associated with the inner-circle of the philosopher Socrates

persons.description: Roman emperor from 79 to 81.

persons.name: Martin afPontin
